title: Figure (Mbulu Ngulu)

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of wood, brass, copper, and iron.

artist_display:
Kota: Mindumu or Obamba
Gabon
Central Africa
description: Figures related to ongoing communion with the ancestors were once widespread among the various Kota peoples. Reducing the human form to flattened planes, artists accentuated these sculptures with sheets and strips of brass and copper. The metal connoted prosperity while its reflective quality was understood to frighten away evil. The figures’ abstraction inspired the Cubists and other modern European artists in the early 20th century to explore forms of repre-sentation that are not rooted in visual reality.
credit_line: Charles H. and Mary F. Worcester Collection Fund
publication_history:
John C. Galloway, Modern Art: The Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries (Dubuque: W.C. Brown Company Publishers, 1967), p. 72, fig. 62.

Roy Sieber, Anspach Collection, exh. cat. (Notre Dame, Ind.: University of Notre Dame Art Gallery, 1968), no. 77. 

George Nelson Preston, The Innovative African Sculptor, exh. cat. (Ithaca, N.Y.: Ithaca College Museum of Art, 1970), p. 37, no. 61, p. 56, no. 61 (discussed).

George Nelson Preston, African Sculpture: Rare and Familiar Forms from the Anspach Collection, exh. cat. (Potsdam, N.Y.: Brainerd Hall Art Gallery, State University College at Potsdam, 1973), no. 3

Alain and Françoise Chaffin, L’Art Kota: Les figure de reliquaire (Meudon: Chaffin, 1979), p. 263, no. 159.

Constantine Petridis et al., Speaking of Objects: African Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2020), p. 138, fig. 1.
exhibition_history:
University of Notre Dame Art Gallery, Anspach Collection, March 17-May 12, 1968, n.pag., no. 77.

Ithaca College Museum of Art, The Innovative African Sculptor, Nov. 11-Dec. 21, 1969, p. 37, no. 61, p. 56, no. 61 (discussed); traveled to Hamilton, N.Y., The Picker Art Gallery, Colgate University, Feb. 15-March 15, 1970.

Potsdam, N.Y., Brainerd Hall Art Gallery, African Sculpture: Rare and Familiar Forms from the Anspach Collection, 1973, n.pag., no. 3.

Kimbell Art Museum, Forth Worth, Texas, "The Language of Beauty in African Art", April 3-July 31, 2022.
provenance_text: John J. Klejman (died 1995), Klejman Gallery, New York, N.Y., by 1962 [Preston 1973, no. 3]; sold to Ernst Anspach (died 2002), New York, NY, from 1962 until at least 1979 [Chaffin 1979, p. 263, no. 159]. Unknown private collection, Paris, France, before 2006 [personal communication from Steven Morris documented in curatorial file]; Lance and Roberta Entwistle and Co., London, and Steven Morris, Donald Morris Gallery, New York, NY and Birmingham, Mich., 2006 [personal communication from Steven Morris documented in curatorial file]; sold to the Art Institute, 2007.
